briefing.opening: Good morning/afternoon. I will now begin the climate change specialist spokesperson briefing for January 28, 2026.

sections.title: ğŸ”´ Worsening Climate Crisis and Global Impact
sections.content: Over the past three years, 'unfamiliar climate change' has been observed [2], and the trend of rising temperatures due to climate change is becoming more pronounced [65]. Last year, South Korea's carbon dioxide emissions reached an all-time high, clearly indicating the impact of climate change [10], and the New Retail Research Institute cited climate change and supply-demand instability as one of the biggest issues this year, warning of ripple effects across the economy [5]. Internationally, Africa is directly hit by climate change, facing droughts and floods, and the potential for an additional 500,000 malaria deaths by 2050 [4, 68, 72, 73, 76, 98, 114], while New York City's bridges and subways are also damaged or face adaptation challenges due to the effects of climate change [78, 89]. In the Somerset region of the UK, floods have occurred, leading residents to question water management [111], and in the 2026 housing insurance market, climate change has been identified as a major cause of rising premiums and increasing consumer complaints [82, 95, 100]. This situation is accompanied by warnings that climate change is accelerating the ticking of the 'Doomsday Clock,' and even cultural perspectives suggesting that 'hatred and despair' arise within the context of climate change [107, 11].

sections.title: ğŸŒ± Innovation and Policies for Domestic Carbon Neutrality Implementation
sections.content: The establishment of eco-friendly welfare infrastructure to address climate change is being promoted [1], and corporate efforts are continuing, with Hyundai Steel, for example, achieving a 'Leadership A-' rating in the CDP Climate Change Response assessment [3, 8, 13]. In Busan, a closed nursing home has been reopened as an ESG center, serving as a 'carbon-neutral hub' [15], and the Incheon City Council is discussing the revitalization of wooden architecture, proposing it as a carbon-neutral solution [16, 17, 22, 26, 34, 37, 38, 106]. Sejong City Council member Hong Na-young emphasized the leading role of the public sector and sustainable carbon neutrality and climate crisis response through 'inspiring administration' [18, 27, 33]. Local governments and industrial complexes such as Jincheon-gun, Changwon-si, Gumi-si, Yeosu Industrial Complex, and Daegu-si are also accelerating the realization of carbon neutrality through initiatives like the Eco-Money project, promotion of buildings, transportation, and circular economy, a two-track strategy for advanced industries and carbon neutrality, exploration of carbon-neutral cooperation models, and the carbon-neutral points system [21, 24, 25, 28, 29]. The Korea Transportation Safety Authority is hiring research assistants for carbon neutrality in the transportation sector [31], and Yesan-gun is making efforts to open up the future through 'carbon-neutral forests' [32]. These diverse efforts are underway for 'carbon neutrality,' which has been presented as a realistic challenge and a guiding principle for the Korean economy in 2026 [23].

sections.title: ğŸ‡°ğŸ‡· Accelerating Energy Transition Centered on Renewable Energy
sections.content: President Lee emphasized that the large-scale supply of renewable energy is the only solution to secure South Korea's electricity cost competitiveness [41, 45, 50, 56, 59, 61], and expressed a commitment to international cooperation for energy security and the establishment of a robust renewable energy ecosystem [57]. With the increasing electricity demand in the era of 'Great AI,' renewable energy is expected to become a cornerstone of future energy mix policies [42], and while offshore wind power is presented as key to achieving 2050 carbon neutrality, changes in the division of roles between renewable energy and nuclear power are anticipated due to new nuclear power plant promotion policies [30, 43, 47]. Haenam-gun urged the enactment of a special law for renewable energy self-sufficient cities and requested support from the government and the National Assembly [39, 44, 53, 54, 60], and regional efforts are also active, with the Wonju Regional Environmental Office signing an MOU to expand renewable energy supply in the Gangwon and Chungbuk regions [46, 48, 55]. The completion of East-West Power's Jeju BESS is expected to contribute to resolving renewable energy output limitations [49], and in Seoul, cases of electricity generation within the city through citizen-participatory renewable energy have also been reported [51]. South Korea has participated in the pledge to triple renewable energy, but numerous challenges remain, including costs and separation distances [52].

sections.title: ğŸŒ International Community's Legal Responsibility and Response to Climate Change
sections.content: In the international community, legal responsibility for climate change response is being strengthened. The Dutch government received a court order to protect residents of the Caribbean island of Bonaire from climate change and to rectify climate adaptation-related discrimination [66, 69, 70, 71, 80, 81, 84, 90, 92, 93, 96, 103, 104, 105, 110], setting an important precedent with the victory of small island residents in a climate change lawsuit [93]. In Wisconsin, USA, a lawsuit regarding climate change has been filed [67], and Connecticut lawmakers are discussing whether to mandate polluters bear the costs of climate change [74]. The UN Climate Change Mitigation Registry will enable cross-border data exchange [88], and enhanced international cooperation is accelerating global transparency efforts [94]. In Australia, the reintroduction of carbon pricing through a 'polluter pays' levy system and proposals for household compensation are being made [112], and in various countries, legal and institutional approaches to climate change mitigation are expanding.

sections.title: ğŸ“° Climate Change Discourse and Shifting Social Perceptions
sections.content: Domestically, it has been reported that 7 out of 10 North Chungcheong Province residents are interested in the climate crisis [9], demonstrating a rising awareness across society. It has been confirmed that the 2026 UN Climate Change Conference Climate Week will be held in Yeosu, South Korea [12], preparing a large-scale international forum with participation from over 200 countries worldwide. Scotland is developing its climate change plan from 2026 to 2040, seeking long-term responses [102], and King Charles III has stated that he has not wavered in his commitment to environmental activism despite past criticisms [109]. Meanwhile, diverse perspectives and discussions on climate change also exist, such as an opinion piece published stating 'The real environmental crisis is not climate change' [91], or research suggesting that ship fuel emissions may not impact climate change [79]. A warning also emerges that increased focus on climate adaptation and development should not sideline emissions reduction [99].

briefing.closing: As we have seen in today's briefing, climate change is emerging as a global threat, yet simultaneously, various domestic and international efforts to overcome it are ongoing. Moving forward, sustained interest and participation are required for international cooperation and the promotion of innovative policies to address climate change. This concludes today's climate briefing.
